trial_identification.studytitle: Use of the Bottle/Bubble Positive Expiratory Pressure (PEP) device by Physiotherapists in Australian hospitals for treating people with respiratory disorders.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Use of the Bottle/Bubble Positive Expiratory Pressure (PEP) device by Physiotherapists in Australian hospitals for treating people with respiratory disorders.

conditions.healthcondition: Physiotherapists in Australia treating people with Respiratory Disorders.

interventions.interventions:
The study will use a questionnaire that will be sent to all specialist paediatric hospitals in Australia and to a representative sample of public and private hospitals in Australia. The physiotherapists working in these hospitals will be invited to participate in the study.
The aims of the questionnaire are to determine: 1) the extent of the Bottle/Bubble PEP use in Australia; 2) the proposed rationale for its use; 3) for which patients Bottle/Bubble PEP is used and; 4) why it is chosen rather than other PEP devices.
The questionnaire is to be returned 1 month after it is mailed out. If the questionnaire is not returned after a month, respondents will be invited again to participate in the study. Maximum length of this study is 6 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: How widespread is the use of the Bottle/Bubble PEP device by physiotherapists in Australia.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The proposed rationale for the Bottle/Bubble PEP use
For which patients Bottle/Bubble PEP is used
Why is the Bottle/Bubble PEP chosen rather than other devices.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Physiotherapists in Australia that treat people with respiratory disorders.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Physiotherapists not treating people with respiratory disorders; non-physiotherapists

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Physiotherapy Department Prince of Wales Hospital Barker Street, Randwick, NSW, 2031

ethicsAndSummary.summary: It is believed that physiotherapists in Australia use the Bottle/Bubble PEP device to treat patients that have secretion clearance problems. It is unknown though to what extent it is used or the rationale behind its use. This questionnaire will assist in answering these questions at it will be sent to a representative sample of physiotherapists working in hospitals within Australia.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: South Eastern Sydney Local Health District - Northern Sector Human Research Ethics Committee
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Prince of Wales Hospital, Barker Street, Randwick, NSW, 2031
